questions.uddipok:
Read the following passage and make a flow chart showing the principles of ecotourism set forth by the International Ecotourism Society (No. 1 has been done for you.)
Ecotourism is broadly defined as low impact travel to endangered and often undisturbed locations. It is different from traditional tourism because it allows the traveller to become educated about the areas-both in terms of the physical landscape and cultural characteristics. It often provides funds for conservation and benefits the economic development of places that are often impoverished.
Due to the growing popularity of environmentally-related and adventure travel, various types of trips are now being classified as ecotourism. Most of these are not truly ecotourism, however, because they do not emphasize conservation, education, low impact travel, and social and cultural participation in the locations being visited.
Therefore, to be considered ecotourism, a trip must meet the following principles set forth by the International Ecotourism Society (TIES: 2015):
• Minimize the impact of visiting the location (i. e. the use of roads)
• Build respect and awareness of the travelers for the environment and cultural practices.
• Ensure that the tourism provides positive experiences for both the travelers and the hosts.
• Provide direct financial aid for conservation.
• Provide financial aid, empowerment and other benefits for local peoples.
• Raise travellers' awareness of the host country's political, environmental and social climate.

1. Minimizing the impact of visiting the location. → 2. → 3. → 4. → 5. → 6.

questions.uddipok:
Summarize the following passage.
We spend money for different reasons. We buy foods, clothes or everyday essentials, pay for different services, entertain people, travel to places, help others in need or invest in business and thus spend money every day. In fact, spending is a part of our life.
Spending may make us happy or unhappy depending on how and why we spend. When we spend money on things that we need and within our limit, it is good. When it becomes a compulsive behaviour, it makes life stressful. Unnecessary spending or spending beyond one's means has some bad effects. For one thing, it may lead to financial ruin or debt, and for another,. it may create unhappiness within families. People who overspend are never satisfied with what they have. They always rush for brands, fashion items, designer clothes, etc. Over a period of time, it becomes an addiction which may eventually create psychological problems.
Nowadays, consumer items are displayed in stores or in advertisements in ways that they create a feeling of immediate need for them. We are constantly tempted to buy, use or consume things even when we do not have a genuine need. We all need to be careful here. Salespersons often encourage customers to buy things by flattering them. 'This is a perfect match for you,' they would say. or 'You look so stunning in that dress.' Never forget, they say the same thing to most of their customers. It is better not to be persuaded by such words. They use these words to please the customers as the more a customer buys, the higher the profit is. Overspending is not only related to shopping, it applies to other activities as well such as eating out. Many people buy too many items to eat in a restaurant. They can eat only some of them and the rest are wasted: It's not a responsible attitude. We cannot simply waste food because we have money to buy it.
Young people in a shopping mall often look at an item on display afd think 'Oh I must buy this. I really need this.' They may not have the money needed. In their wallet. So, they use credit cards but using them is like taking a loan. If they are not careful, the loans increase which might lead them to a debt-trap.
Sometimes children insist on buying things that their parents cannot pay without stretching their budget. This may happen because the children's friends also have them. It's not fair as it becomes a burden for the parents.
Finally, don't get trapped by the glossy advertisements on television or the Internet. You should rather ask yourself: "Do I need this?" The best way to control the habit of spending is not to think 'What I need', but 'Can I do without it?'

sub_questions.explanation: Money is spent every day for various reasons. Necessary expenses within our limit may make us happy. But unnecessary expenditure or spending money beyond our ability creates some problems and may lead to psychological problems. At present, consumer items are exhibited and advertised so attractively that we want to buy them immediately even without having a genuine need. Salespersons often flatter the customers to encourage them to buy more things. Buying more foods than requirements and their wastage means wastage of money. Children also make their parents fall in economic crisis by pressurizing them to buy unnecessary things. We should restrain this habit of overspending by asking ourselves if we can do without the thing we feel tempted to buy.

questions.uddipok:
The following is the beginning of the story, complete it in your own words :
Once upon a time there lived a king in England. He had three daughters. One day he made up his mind to divide his kingdom among them. So, he called them in the court and asked each of them how much they loved him …………….

sub_questions.explanation:
Once upon a time there lived a king in England. He had three daughters. One day he made up his mind to divide his kingdom among them. So, he called them in the court and asked each of them how much they loved him.
Goneril, the eldest, stepped forward first. “Father, I love you more than all the diamonds and treasures of the world!” she exclaimed. The king beamed and gave her a generous portion of his realm.
Next came Regan the second daughter. “Dear father,” she said, “my love for you shall never change—it is as deep as the sea and as constant as the stars.” Again, the king was pleased and granted her an equal share.
Finally, his youngest and dearest daughter, Cordelia, came before him. With a gentle voice, she said, “Father, I love you as much as the salt upon our tables. Without it, food has no flavor—so life is dull without you.” Her honest words surprised the court.
The king’s face darkened. He thought, How ungrateful! He dramatically dismissed her: “Salt? Unfit! You shall receive nothing! Begone from this kingdom!”
Banished, Cordelia wandered into the forest in tears. As fate would have it, a kind prince found her among the trees. Impressed by her purity and calm strength, he married her and brought her to his kingdom, while Cordelia never forgot her father.
Back home, the king’s life grew tasteless—his meals had no joy, his lands were split, and his daughters, blinded by vanity, turned away. In his loneliness, he realized Cordelia’s words were wise: just as salt gives flavor to food, her simple truth brought life to his heart.
Filled with regret, he sent messengers far and wide to beg her return. Cordelia returned at the head of her husband’s court, salt in hand, and lovingly reconciled with him. The king restored her share, reunited his heart, and lived his remaining days in peace and gratitude.

questions.uddipok: Write a letter to your younger brother/sister advising him/her not to share fake or baseless news on his/her social media account.

sub_questions.explanation:
Subject: Importance of Responsible Social Media Sharing
Dear [Younger Brother/Sister's Name],
I hope this letter finds you well. As your older sibling, I feel it's important to share some advice regarding your social media activities, particularly concerning the sharing of news articles and information.
In today's digital age, social media has become a powerful tool for communication and information sharing. While it offers numerous benefits, it also comes with certain responsibilities. One of these responsibilities is ensuring that the information we share is accurate, reliable, and credible.
I've noticed that lately, you've been sharing a lot of news articles and stories on your social media accounts without verifying their authenticity. While I understand the urge to stay informed and share interesting content with your friends and followers, it's crucial to remember that not everything you come across on the internet is true.
Sharing fake or baseless news can have serious consequences. Not only does it contribute to the spread of misinformation, but it can also harm the reputations of individuals and organizations unfairly targeted by false claims. Moreover, it can fuel unnecessary panic and confusion among people who may believe the misinformation to be true.
Before sharing any news article or story on your social media accounts, I urge you to take a moment to verify its credibility. Look for reliable sources, cross-check the information with other reputable news outlets, and consider the context in which the story is presented. If you're unsure about the accuracy of a particular piece of news, it's better to refrain from sharing it altogether.
Remember that as a member of the online community, you have the power to influence others with the content you share. By being mindful of the information you share and prioritizing accuracy and credibility, you can contribute to a more informed and responsible digital environment.
If you ever come across news or information that you're unsure about, don't hesitate to reach out to me or other trusted sources for guidance. Together, we can work towards promoting responsible social media behavior and combating the spread of misinformation.
Thank you for taking the time to read this letter, and please know that I'm always here to offer support and guidance whenever you need it.
Take care, and I look forward to seeing you soon.
Warm regards,
[Your Name]
